  • havoc.autoval.tests.pcie_bifurcation_test.pcie_bifurcation_test

Source code for havoc.autoval.tests.pcie_bifurcation_test.pcie_bifurcation_test

from __future__ import absolute_import, division, print_function, unicode_literals
from havoc.autoval.lib.test_base import TestBase
from havoc.autoval.lib.test_utils.pci_utils import PciUtils



[docs]class PcieBifurcationTest(TestBase):

[docs]    def __init__(self):
        super(PcieBifurcationTest, self).__init__()
        self.device_id = self.test_control.get("device_id", None)
        self.m2type = self.test_control.get("Mdot2_type", None)
        self.m2id = self.test_control.get("Mdot2_id", {})
        self.current_config = {"gen3" : [], "gen2" : [], "off" : []}
        self.num_of_m2 = self.test_control.get("num_of_mdot2", 0)
        self.pciUtils = PciUtils()



[docs]    def execute(self):
        self.log_info("Executing PCie Bifurcation test for Gpv2")
        pcie_ports = self.host.get_device_ports()

        # Validate if its a GPv2 system with 2 x16width 11f8:
        if self.device_id:
            self.validateGPv2(pcie_ports["switch"])

        # Validate the information of the respective device is found
        if self.num_of_m2:
            self.findall_gpv2_devices(pcie_ports["mdot2"])



[docs]    def validateGPv2(self, switch_port):
        '''
        This validates the LnkCap & LnkSta matches for Speed & Width
        for 2 ports for qualifying GPv2
        '''
        self.log_info("Validating GPv2 switch Link")
        for _key, _port in switch_port.items():
            lspci_out = self.pciUtils.get_lnksta_lnkcap_port(
                self.host,
                port=_port,
                device=self.device_id
            )
            #validate that the sta_width is x16 for GPv2
            self.validate_equal(
                lspci_out["sta_width"],
                "x16",
                "Validating LnkSta Width {} for GPv2 matches x16"
                .format(_port)
            )
            #check the LnkCap speed matches LnkSta speed
            self.validate_equal(
                lspci_out["cap_speed"],
                lspci_out["sta_speed"],
                "Validating LnkCap and LnkSta speed for {} for GPv2"
                .format(_port)
            )
            #check the LnkCap width matches LnkSta width
            self.validate_equal(
                lspci_out["cap_width"],
                lspci_out["sta_width"],
                "Validating LnkCap and LnkSta width {} for GPv2"
                .format(_port)
            )



[docs]    def findall_gpv2_devices(self, m2_ports):
        '''
        Makes use of the Bridge port address in host file to
        validate and identify current system configuration for M.2 devices
        '''
        self.log_info("Validating M.2 devices")
        for _port_num, _port in m2_ports.items():
            # retrieve the lspci port info
            out = self.pciUtils.get_lnksta_lnkcap_port(
                self.host,
                port=_port,
                device=self.device_id
            )
            #check if the LnkSta: speed shows correctly as Gen3
            if ('8GT' == out['sta_speed']):
                self.current_config["gen3"].append(_port)
                if out["secondary_port"]:
                    self.parse_for_device_type(out["secondary_port"], _port_num)
            elif ('5GT' == out['sta_speed']):
                self.validate_condition(
                    False,
                    "Device on {} is @ Gen2 speed".format(_port_num),
                    raise_on_fail=False
                )
                self.current_config["gen2"].append(_port)
            else:
                self.validate_condition(
                    False,
                    "Device on {} not found".format(_port_num),
                    raise_on_fail=False
                )
                self.current_config["off"].append(_port)
        # Shows the current config as discovered on server
        self.log_info("Config found on system: {}".format(self.current_config))
        # verify the test_control provided no. of devices matches
        self.validate_equal(
            len(self.current_config["gen3"]),
            self.num_of_m2,
            "Verifying given count matches found count of M.2 devices"
        )



[docs]    def parse_for_device_type(self, port, port_num):
        '''
        PMC-Sierra Inc --> connected to --> Processing Accelerators
        This function finds out details and data corresponding to
        Processing Accelerators.

        From json file:
        self.m2id = { "Processing Accelerator" : 5e87,
                        "Inference Card" : <id>}  <<-- future add

        This should be able to verify any future card.
        '''
        for desc, dev_id in self.m2id.items():
            # read the lspci data for secondary bus/M.2 card
            dev_lspci_out = self.pciUtils.get_lnksta_lnkcap_port(
                self.host, port=port, device=dev_id
            )
            #validate that we have lspci output
            # no lspci output means the device is bad
            self.validate_condition(dev_lspci_out,
                "Verified {} info found at {}".format(desc, port),
                raise_on_fail=False)




[docs]def main():
    test = PcieBifurcationTest()
    test.lifecycle()



if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
